Advisement: A d v i s e m e n t "n. Counsel; advice; information.

Advisement: A d v i s e m e n t "n. Consideration; deliberation; consultation.

Adviser: A d v i s e r "n. One who advises.

Advisership: A d v i s e r s h i p "n. The office of an adviser.

Advising: A d v i s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Advise

Adviso: A d v i s o "n. Advice; counsel; suggestion; also  a dispatch or advice boat.

Advisory: A d v i s o r y "a. Having power to advise; containing advice; as  an advisory council; their opinion is merely advisory.

Advocacy: A d v o c a c y "n. The act of pleading for or supporting; work of advocating; intercession.

Advocate: A d v o c a t e "n. One who pleads the cause of another. Specifically: One who pleads the cause of another before a tribunal or judicial court; a counselor.

Advocate: A d v o c a t e "n. One who defends  vindicates or espouses any cause by argument; a pleader; as an advocate of free trade an advocate of truth.

Advocate: A d v o c a t e "n. Christ  considered as an intercessor.

Advocate: A d v o c a t e "n. To plead in favor of; to defend by argument  before a tribunal or the public; to support vindicate or recommend publicly.

Advocate: A d v o c a t e "v. i. To act as advocate.

Advocated: A d v o c a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Advocate

Advocateship: A d v o c a t e s h i p "n. Office or duty of an advocate.

Advocating: A d v o c a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Advocate

Advocation: A d v o c a t i o n "n. The act of advocating or pleading; plea; advocacy.

Advocation: A d v o c a t i o n "n. Advowson.

Advocation: A d v o c a t i o n "n. The process of removing a cause from an inferior court to the supreme court.

Advocatory: A d v o c a t o r y "a. Of or pertaining to an advocate.

Advoke: A d v o k e "v. t. To summon; to call.

Advolution: A d v o l u t i o n "n. A rolling toward something.

Advoutrer: A d v o u t r e r "n. An adulterer.

Advoutress: A d v o u t r e s s "n. An adulteress.

Advoutry: A d v o u t r y "n. Alt. of Advowtry

Advowee: A d v o w e e "n. One who has an advowson.

Advowson: A d v o w s o n "n. The right of presenting to a vacant benefice or living in the church. [Originally  the relation of a patron (advocatus) or protector of a benefice and thus privileged to nominate or present to it.]

Advowtry: A d v o w t r y "n. Adultery.

Advoyer: A d v o y e r "n. See Avoyer.

Adward: A d w a r d "n. Award.

Adynamia: A d y n a m i a "n. Considerable debility of the vital powers  as in typhoid fever.

Adynamic: A d y n a m i c "a. Pertaining to  or characterized by debility of the vital powers; weak.

Adynamic: A d y n a m i c "a. Characterized by the absence of power or force.

Adynamy: A d y n a m y "n. Adynamia.

Adyta: A d y t a "pl. "of Adytum

Adytum: A d y t u m "n. The innermost sanctuary or shrine in ancient temples  whence oracles were given. Hence: A private chamber; a sanctum.

Adz: A d z "n. Alt. of Adze

Adz: A d z "v. t. To cut with an adz.

Adze: A d z e "n. A carpenter's or cooper's tool  formed with a thin arching blade set at right angles to the handle. It is used for chipping or slicing away the surface of wood.

Ae: A e " Alt. of Ae

Ae: A e " A diphthong in the Latin language; used also by the Saxon writers. It answers to the Gr. ai. The Anglo-Saxon short ae was generally replaced by a  the long / by e or ee. In derivatives from Latin words with ae it is mostly superseded by e. For most words found with this initial combination the reader will therefore search under the letter E.

Aecidia: A e c i d i a "pl. "of Aecidium

Aecidium: A e c i d i u m "n. A form of fruit in the cycle of development of the Rusts or Brands  an order of fungi formerly considered independent plants.

Aedile: A e d i l e "n. A magistrate in ancient Rome  who had the superintendence of public buildings highways shows etc.; hence a municipal officer.

Aedileship: A e d i l e s h i p "n. The office of an aedile.

Aegean: A e g e a n "a. Of or pertaining to the sea  or arm of the Mediterranean sea east of Greece. See Archipelago.

Aegicrania: A e g i c r a n i a "n. pl. Sculptured ornaments  used in classical architecture representing rams' heads or skulls.

Aegilops: A e g i l o p s "n. An ulcer or fistula in the inner corner of the eye.

Aegilops: A e g i l o p s "n. The great wild-oat grass or other cornfield weed.

Aegilops: A e g i l o p s "n. A genus of plants  called also hardgrass.

Aegis: A e g i s "n. A shield or protective armor; -- applied in mythology to the shield of Jupiter which he gave to Minerva. Also fig.: A shield; a protection.

Aegophony: A e g o p h o n y "n. Same as Egophony.

Aegrotat: A e g r o t a t "n. A medical certificate that a student is ill.

Aemail ombrant: A e m a i l   o m b r a n t " An art or process of flooding transparent colored glaze over designs stamped or molded on earthenware or porcelain.

Aeneid: A e n e i d "n. The great epic poem of Virgil  of which the hero is Aeneas.

Aeneous: A e n e o u s "a. Colored like bronze.

Aeolian: A e o l i a n "a. Of or pertaining to Aeolia or Aeolis  in Asia Minor colonized by the Greeks or to its inhabitants; aeolic; as the Aeolian dialect.

Aeolian: A e o l i a n "a. Pertaining to Aeolus  the mythic god of the winds; pertaining to or produced by the wind; aerial.

Aeolic: A e o l i c "a. Aeolian  1; as the Aeolic dialect; the Aeolic mode.

Aeolipile: A e o l i p i l e "n. Alt. of Aeolipyle

Aeolipyle: A e o l i p y l e "n. An apparatus consisting chiefly of a closed vessel (as a globe or cylinder) with one or more projecting bent tubes  through which steam is made to pass from the vessel causing it to revolve.

Aeolotropic: A e o l o t r o p i c "a. Exhibiting differences of quality or property in different directions; not isotropic.

Aeolotropy: A e o l o t r o p y "n. Difference of quality or property in different directions.

Aeolus: A e o l u s "n. The god of the winds.

Aeon: A e o n "n. A period of immeasurable duration; also  an emanation of the Deity. See Eon.

Aeon: A e o n "n. An immeasurable or infinite space of time; eternity; a long space of time; an age.

Aeon: A e o n "n. One of the embodiments of the divine attributes of the Eternal Being.

Aeonian: A e o n i a n "a. Eternal; everlasting.

Aepyornis: A e p y o r n i s "n. A gigantic bird found fossil in Madagascar.

Aerate: A e r a t e "v. t. To combine or charge with gas; usually with carbonic acid gas  formerly called fixed air.

Aerate: A e r a t e "v. t. To supply or impregnate with common air; as  to aerate soil; to aerate water.

Aerate: A e r a t e "v. t. To expose to the chemical action of air; to oxygenate (the blood) by respiration; to arterialize.

Aerated: A e r a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Aerate

Aerating: A e r a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Aerate

Aeration: A e r a t i o n "n. Exposure to the free action of the air; airing; as  aeration of soil of spawn etc.

Aeration: A e r a t i o n "n. A change produced in the blood by exposure to the air in respiration; oxygenation of the blood in respiration; arterialization.

Aeration: A e r a t i o n "n. The act or preparation of charging with carbonic acid gas or with oxygen.

Aerator: A e r a t o r "n. That which supplies with air; esp. an apparatus used for charging mineral waters with gas and in making soda water.

Aerial: A e r i a l "a. Of or pertaining to the air  or atmosphere; inhabiting or frequenting the air; produced by or found in the air; performed in the air; as aerial regions or currents.

Aerial: A e r i a l "a. Consisting of air; resembling  or partaking of the nature of air. Hence: Unsubstantial; unreal.

Aerial: A e r i a l "a. Rising aloft in air; high; lofty; as  aerial spires.

Aerial: A e r i a l "a. Growing  forming or existing in the air as opposed to growing or existing in earth or water or underground; as aerial rootlets aerial plants.

Aerial: A e r i a l "a. Light as air; ethereal.

Aeriality: A e r i a l i t y "n. The state of being aerial; unsubstantiality.

Aerially: A e r i a l l y "adv. Like  or from the air; in an aerial manner.

Aerie: A e r i e "n. The nest of a bird of prey  as of an eagle or hawk; also a brood of such birds; eyrie. Shak. Also fig.: A human residence or resting place perched like an eagle's nest.

Aeriferous: A e r i f e r o u s "a. Conveying or containing air; air-bearing; as  the windpipe is an aeriferous tube.

Aerification: A e r i f i c a t i o n "n. The act of combining air with another substance  or the state of being filled with air.

Aerification: A e r i f i c a t i o n "n. The act of becoming aerified  or of changing from a solid or liquid form into an aeriform state; the state of being aeriform.

Aeriform: A e r i f o r m "a. Having the form or nature of air  or of an elastic fluid; gaseous. Hence fig.: Unreal.

Aerify: A e r i f y "v. t. To infuse air into; to combine air with.

Aerify: A e r i f y "v. t. To change into an aeriform state.

Aero-: A e r o - " The combining form of the Greek word meaning air.

Aerobies: A e r o b i e s "n. pl. Microorganisms which live in contact with the air and need oxygen for their growth; as the microbacteria which form on the surface of putrefactive fluids.

Aerobiotic: A e r o b i o t i c "a. Related to  or of the nature of aerobies; as aerobiotic plants which live only when supplied with free oxygen.

Aerocyst: A e r o c y s t "n. One of the air cells of algals.

Aerodynamic: A e r o d y n a m i c "a. Pertaining to the force of air in motion.

Aerodynamics: A e r o d y n a m i c s "n. The science which treats of the air and other gaseous bodies under the action of force  and of their mechanical effects.

Aerognosy: A e r o g n o s y "n. The science which treats of the properties of the air  and of the part it plays in nature.

Aerographer: A e r o g r a p h e r "n. One versed in aeography: an aerologist.

Aerographic: A e r o g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Aerographical

Aerographical: A e r o g r a p h i c a l "a. Pertaining to aerography; aerological.

Aerography: A e r o g r a p h y "n. A description of the air or atmosphere; aerology.

Aerohydrodynamic: A e r o h y d r o d y n a m i c "a. Acting by the force of air and water; as  an aerohydrodynamic wheel.

Aerolite: A e r o l i t e "n. A stone  or metallic mass which has fallen to the earth from distant space; a meteorite; a meteoric stone.

Aerolith: A e r o l i t h "n. Same as A/rolite.

Aerolithology: A e r o l i t h o l o g y "n. The science of aerolites.

Aerolitic: A e r o l i t i c "a. Of or pertaining to aerolites; meteoric; as  aerolitic iron.

Aerologic: A e r o l o g i c "a. Alt. of Aerological

Aerological: A e r o l o g i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to aerology.

Aerologist: A e r o l o g i s t "n. One versed in aerology.

Aerology: A e r o l o g y "n. That department of physics which treats of the atmosphere.

Aeromancy: A e r o m a n c y "n. Divination from the state of the air or from atmospheric substances; also  forecasting changes in the weather.

Aerometer: A e r o m e t e r "n. An instrument for ascertaining the weight or density of air and gases.

Aerometric: A e r o m e t r i c "a. Of or pertaining to aerometry; as  aerometric investigations.

Aerometry: A e r o m e t r y "n. The science of measuring the air  including the doctrine of its pressure elasticity rarefaction and condensation; pneumatics.

Aeronaut: A e r o n a u t "n. An aerial navigator; a balloonist.

Aeronautic: A e r o n a u t i c "a. Alt. of Aeronautical

Aeronautical: A e r o n a u t i c a l "a. Pertaining to aeronautics  or aerial sailing.

Aeronautics: A e r o n a u t i c s "n. The science or art of ascending and sailing in the air  as by means of a balloon; aerial navigation; ballooning.

Aerophobia: A e r o p h o b i a "n. Alt. of Aerophoby

Aerophoby: A e r o p h o b y "n. Dread of a current of air.

Aerophyte: A e r o p h y t e "n. A plant growing entirely in the air  and receiving its nourishment from it; an air plant or epiphyte.

Aeroplane: A e r o p l a n e "n. A flying machine  or a small plane for experiments on flying which floats in the air only when propelled through it.

Aeroscope: A e r o s c o p e "n. An apparatus designed for collecting spores  germs bacteria etc. suspended in the air.

Aeroscopy: A e r o s c o p y "n. The observation of the state and variations of the atmosphere.

Aerose: A e r o s e "a. Of the nature of  or like copper; brassy.

Aerosiderite: A e r o s i d e r i t e "n. A mass of meteoric iron.

Aerosphere: A e r o s p h e r e "n. The atmosphere.

Aerostat: A e r o s t a t "n. A balloon.

Aerostat: A e r o s t a t "n. A balloonist; an aeronaut.

Aerostatic: A e r o s t a t i c "a. Alt. of Aerostatical

Aerostatical: A e r o s t a t i c a l "a. Of or pertaining to aerostatics; pneumatic.

Aerostatical: A e r o s t a t i c a l "a. Aeronautic; as  an aerostatic voyage.

Aerostatics: A e r o s t a t i c s "n. The science that treats of the equilibrium of elastic fluids  or that of bodies sustained in them. Hence it includes aeronautics.

Aerostation: A e r o s t a t i o n "n. Aerial navigation; the art of raising and guiding balloons in the air.

Aerostation: A e r o s t a t i o n "n. The science of weighing air; aerostatics.

Aeruginous: A e r u g i n o u s "a. Of the nature or color of verdigris  or the rust of copper.

Aerugo: A e r u g o "n. The rust of any metal  esp. of brass or copper; verdigris.

Aery: A e r y "n. An aerie.

Aery: A e r y "a. Aerial; ethereal; incorporeal; visionary.

Aesculapian: A e s c u l a p i a n "a. Pertaining to Aesculapius or to the healing art; medical; medicinal.

Aesculapius: A e s c u l a p i u s "n. The god of medicine. Hence  a physician.

Aesculin: A e s c u l i n "n. Same as Esculin.

Aesopic: A e s o p i c "a. Alt. of Esopic

Aesthesia: A e s t h e s i a "n. Perception by the senses; feeling; -- the opposite of anaesthesia.

Aesthesiometer: A e s t h e s i o m e t e r "n. Alt. of Esthesiometer

Aesthesis: A e s t h e s i s "n. Sensuous perception.

Aesthesodic: A e s t h e s o d i c "a. Conveying sensory or afferent impulses; -- said of nerves.

Aesthete: A e s t h e t e "n. One who makes much or overmuch of aesthetics.

Aesthetic: A e s t h e t i c "a. Alt. of Aesthetical

Aesthetical: A e s t h e t i c a l "a. Of or Pertaining to aesthetics; versed in aesthetics; as  aesthetic studies emotions ideas persons etc.

Aesthetican: A e s t h e t i c a n "n. One versed in aesthetics.

Aestheticism: A e s t h e t i c i s m "n. The doctrine of aesthetics; aesthetic principles; devotion to the beautiful in nature and art.

Aesthetics: A e s t h e t i c s "n. Alt. of Esthetics

Aestho-physiology: A e s t h o - p h y s i o l o g y "n. The science of sensation in relation to nervous action.

Aestival: A e s t i v a l "a. Of or belonging to the summer; as  aestival diseases.

Aestivate: A e s t i v a t e "v. i. To spend the summer.

Aestivate: A e s t i v a t e "v. i. To pass the summer in a state of torpor.

Aestivation: A e s t i v a t i o n "n. The state of torpidity induced by the heat and dryness of summer  as in certain snails; -- opposed to hibernation.

Aestivation: A e s t i v a t i o n "n. The arrangement of the petals in a flower bud  as to folding overlapping etc.; prefloration.

Aestuary: A e s t u a r y "n. & a. See Estuary.

Aestuous: A e s t u o u s "a. Glowing; agitated  as with heat.

Aetheogamous: A e t h e o g a m o u s "a. Propagated in an unusual way; cryptogamous.

Aether: A e t h e r "n. See Ether.

Aethiops mineral: A e t h i o p s   m i n e r a l " Same as Ethiops mineral.

Aethogen: A e t h o g e n "n. A compound of nitrogen and boro/  which when heated before the blowpipe gives a brilliant phosphorescent; boric nitride.

Aethrioscope: A e t h r i o s c o p e "n. An instrument consisting in part of a differential thermometer. It is used for measuring changes of temperature produced by different conditions of the sky  as when clear or clouded.

Aetiological: A e t i o l o g i c a l "a. Pertaining to aetiology; assigning a cause.

Aetiology: A e t i o l o g y "n. The science  doctrine or demonstration of causes; esp. the investigation of the causes of any disease; the science of the origin and development of things.

Aetiology: A e t i o l o g y "n. The assignment of a cause.

Aetites: A e t i t e s "n. See Eaglestone.

Afar: A f a r "adv. At  to or from a great distance; far away; -- often used with from preceding or off following; as he was seen from afar; I saw him afar off.

Afeard: A f e a r d "p. a. Afraid.

Afer: A f e r "n. The southwest wind.

Affability: A f f a b i l i t y "n. The quality of being affable; readiness to converse; courteousness in receiving others and in conversation; complaisant behavior.

Affable: A f f a b l e "a. Easy to be spoken to or addressed; receiving others kindly and conversing with them in a free and friendly manner; courteous; sociable.

Affable: A f f a b l e "a. Gracious; mild; benign.

Affableness: A f f a b l e n e s s "n. Affability.

Affably: A f f a b l y "adv. In an affable manner; courteously.

Affabrous: A f f a b r o u s "a. Executed in a workmanlike manner; ingeniously made.

Affair: A f f a i r "n. That which is done or is to be done; matter; concern; as  a difficult affair to manage; business of any kind commercial professional or public; -- often in the plural. At the head of affairs. Junius.

Affair: A f f a i r "n. Any proceeding or action which it is wished to refer to or characterize vaguely; as  an affair of honor i. e. a duel; an affair of love i. e. an intrigue.

Affair: A f f a i r "n. An action or engagement not of sufficient magnitude to be called a battle.

Affair: A f f a i r "n. Action; endeavor.

Affair: A f f a i r "n. A material object (vaguely designated).

Affect: A f f e c t "v. t. To act upon; to produce an effect or change upon.

Affect: A f f e c t "v. t. To influence or move  as the feelings or passions; to touch.

Affect: A f f e c t "v. t. To love; to regard with affection.

Affect: A f f e c t "v. t. To dispose or incline.

Affect: A f f e c t "v. t. To aim at; to aspire; to covet.

Affect: A f f e c t "v. t. To tend to by affinity or disposition.

Affect: A f f e c t "n. Affection; inclination; passion; feeling; disposition.

Affectation: A f f e c t a t i o n "n. An attempt to assume or exhibit what is not natural or real; false display; artificial show.

Affectation: A f f e c t a t i o n "n. A striving after.

Affectation: A f f e c t a t i o n "n. Fondness; affection.

Affectationist: A f f e c t a t i o n i s t "n. One who exhibits affectation.

Affected: A f f e c t e d "imp. & p. p. of Affect

Affected: A f f e c t e d "p. p. & a. Regarded with affection; beloved.

Affected: A f f e c t e d "p. p. & a. Inclined; disposed; attached.

Affected: A f f e c t e d "p. p. & a. Given to false show; assuming or pretending to possess what is not natural or real.

Affected: A f f e c t e d "p. p. & a. Assumed artificially; not natural.

Affected: A f f e c t e d "p. p. & a. Made up of terms involving different powers of the unknown quantity; adfected; as  an affected equation.

Affectedly: A f f e c t e d l y "adv. In an affected manner; hypocritically; with more show than reality.

Affectedly: A f f e c t e d l y "adv. Lovingly; with tender care.

Affectedness: A f f e c t e d n e s s "n. Affectation.

Affecter: A f f e c t e r "n. One who affects  assumes pretends or strives after.

Affectibility: A f f e c t i b i l i t y "n. The quality or state of being affectible.

Affectible: A f f e c t i b l e "a. That may be affected.

Affecting: A f f e c t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Affect

Affecting: A f f e c t i n g "a. Moving the emotions; fitted to excite the emotions; pathetic; touching; as  an affecting address; an affecting sight.

Affecting: A f f e c t i n g "a. Affected; given to false show.

Affectingly: A f f e c t i n g l y "adv. In an affecting manner; is a manner to excite emotions.

Affection: A f f e c t i o n "n. The act of affecting or acting upon; the state of being affected.

Affection: A f f e c t i o n "n. An attribute; a quality or property; a condition; a bodily state; as  figure weight etc. are affections of bodies.

Affection: A f f e c t i o n "n. Bent of mind; a feeling or natural impulse or natural impulse acting upon and swaying the mind; any emotion; as  the benevolent affections esteem gratitude etc.; the malevolent affections hatred envy etc.; inclination; disposition; propensity; tendency.

Affection: A f f e c t i o n "n. A settled good will; kind feeling; love; zealous or tender attachment; -- often in the pl. Formerly followed by to  but now more generally by for or towards; as filial social or conjugal affections; to have an affection for or towards children.

Affection: A f f e c t i o n "n. Prejudice; bias.

Affection: A f f e c t i o n "n. Disease; morbid symptom; malady; as  a pulmonary affection.

Affection: A f f e c t i o n "n. The lively representation of any emotion.

Affection: A f f e c t i o n "n. Affectation.

Affection: A f f e c t i o n "n. Passion; violent emotion.

Affectional: A f f e c t i o n a l "a. Of or pertaining to the affections; as  affectional impulses; an affectional nature.

Affectionate: A f f e c t i o n a t e "a. Having affection or warm regard; loving; fond; as  an affectionate brother.

Affectionate: A f f e c t i o n a t e "a. Kindly inclined; zealous.

Affectionate: A f f e c t i o n a t e "a. Proceeding from affection; indicating love; tender; as  the affectionate care of a parent; affectionate countenance message language.

Affectionate: A f f e c t i o n a t e "a. Strongly inclined; -- with to.

Affectionated: A f f e c t i o n a t e d "a. Disposed; inclined.

Affectionately: A f f e c t i o n a t e l y "adv. With affection; lovingly; fondly; tenderly; kindly.

Affectionateness: A f f e c t i o n a t e n e s s "n. The quality of being affectionate; fondness; affection.

Affectioned: A f f e c t i o n e d "a. Disposed.

Affectioned: A f f e c t i o n e d "a. Affected; conceited.

Affective: A f f e c t i v e "a. Tending to affect; affecting.

Affective: A f f e c t i v e "a. Pertaining to or exciting emotion; affectional; emotional.

Affectively: A f f e c t i v e l y "adv. In an affective manner; impressively; emotionally.

Affectuous: A f f e c t u o u s "a. Full of passion or emotion; earnest.

Affeer: A f f e e r "v. t. To confirm; to assure.

Affeer: A f f e e r "v. t. To assess or reduce  as an arbitrary penalty or amercement to a certain and reasonable sum.

Affeerer: A f f e e r e r "n. Alt. of Affeeror

Affeerment: A f f e e r m e n t "n. The act of affeering.

Affeeror: A f f e e r o r "n. One who affeers.

Afferent: A f f e r e n t "a. Bearing or conducting inwards to a part or organ; -- opposed to efferent; as  afferent vessels; afferent nerves which convey sensations from the external organs to the brain.

Affettuoso: A f f e t t u o s o "adv. With feeling.

Affiance: A f f i a n c e "n. Plighted faith; marriage contract or promise.

Affiance: A f f i a n c e "n. Trust; reliance; faith; confidence.

Affiliable: A f f i l i a b l e "a. Capable of being affiliated to or on  or connected with in origin.

Affiliate: A f f i l i a t e "v. t. To adopt; to receive into a family as a son; hence  to bring or receive into close connection; to ally.

Affiliate: A f f i l i a t e "v. t. To fix the paternity of; -- said of an illegitimate child; as  to affiliate the child to (or on or upon) one man rather than another.

Affiliate: A f f i l i a t e "v. t. To connect in the way of descent; to trace origin to.

Affiliate: A f f i l i a t e "v. t. To attach (to) or unite (with); to receive into a society as a member  and initiate into its mysteries plans etc.; -- followed by to or with.

Affiliate: A f f i l i a t e "v. i. To connect or associate one's self; -- followed by with; as  they affiliate with no party.

Affiliation: A f f i l i a t i o n "n. Connection in the way of descent.

Affinities: A f f i n i t i e s "pl. "of Affinity

Affinitive: A f f i n i t i v e "a. Closely connected  as by affinity.

Affinity: A f f i n i t y "n. Relationship by marriage (as between a husband and his wife's blood relations  or between a wife and her husband's blood relations); -- in contradistinction to consanguinity or relationship by blood; -- followed by with to or between.

Affinity: A f f i n i t y "n. Kinship generally; close agreement; relation; conformity; resemblance; connection; as  the affinity of sounds of colors or of languages.

Affinity: A f f i n i t y "n. Companionship; acquaintance.

Affinity: A f f i n i t y "n. That attraction which takes place  at an insensible distance between the heterogeneous particles of bodies and unites them to form chemical compounds; chemism; chemical or elective affinity or attraction.

Affinity: A f f i n i t y "n. A relation between species or highe/ groups dependent on resemblance in the whole plan of structure  and indicating community of origin.

Affinity: A f f i n i t y "n. A superior spiritual relationship or attraction held to exist sometimes between persons  esp. persons of the opposite sex; also the man or woman who exerts such psychical or spiritual attraction.

Affirm: A f f i r m "v. t. to assert or confirm  as a judgment decree or order brought before an appellate court for review.

Affirm: A f f i r m "v. t. To assert positively; to tell with confidence; to aver; to maintain as true; -- opposed to deny.

Affirm: A f f i r m "v. t. To declare  as a fact solemnly under judicial sanction. See Affirmation 4.

Affirm: A f f i r m "v. i. To declare or assert positively.

Affirm: A f f i r m "v. i. To make a solemn declaration  before an authorized magistrate or tribunal under the penalties of perjury; to testify by affirmation.

Affirmable: A f f i r m a b l e "a. Capable of being affirmed  asserted or declared; -- followed by of; as an attribute affirmable of every just man.

Affirmance: A f f i r m a n c e "n. Confirmation; ratification; confirmation of a voidable act.

Affirmance: A f f i r m a n c e "n. A strong declaration; affirmation.

Affirmant: A f f i r m a n t "n. One who affirms or asserts.

Affirmant: A f f i r m a n t "n. One who affirms  instead of taking an oath.

Affirmation: A f f i r m a t i o n "n. Confirmation of anything established; ratification; as  the affirmation of a law.

Affirmation: A f f i r m a t i o n "n. The act of affirming or asserting as true; assertion; -- opposed to negation or denial.

Affirmation: A f f i r m a t i o n "n. That which is asserted; an assertion; a positive statement; an averment; as  an affirmation by the vender of title to property sold or of its quality.

Affirmation: A f f i r m a t i o n "n. A solemn declaration made under the penalties of perjury  by persons who conscientiously decline taking an oath which declaration is in law equivalent to an oath.

Affirmative: A f f i r m a t i v e "a. Confirmative; ratifying; as  an act affirmative of common law.

Affirmative: A f f i r m a t i v e "a. That affirms; asserting that the fact is so; declaratory of what exists; answering yes to a question; -- opposed to negative; as  an affirmative answer; an affirmative vote.

Affirmative: A f f i r m a t i v e "a. Positive; dogmatic.

Affirmative: A f f i r m a t i v e "a. Expressing the agreement of the two terms of a proposition.

Affirmative: A f f i r m a t i v e "a. Positive; -- a term applied to quantities which are to be added  and opposed to negative or such as are to be subtracted.

Affirmative: A f f i r m a t i v e "n. That which affirms as opposed to that which denies; an affirmative proposition; that side of question which affirms or maintains the proposition stated; -- opposed to negative; as  there were forty votes in the affirmative and ten in the negative.

Affirmative: A f f i r m a t i v e "n. A word or phrase expressing affirmation or assent; as  yes that is so etc.

Affirmatively: A f f i r m a t i v e l y "adv. In an affirmative manner; on the affirmative side of a question; in the affirmative; -- opposed to negatively.

Affirmatory: A f f i r m a t o r y "a. Giving affirmation; assertive; affirmative.

Affix: A f f i x "v. t. To attach  unite or connect with; as names affixed to ideas or ideas affixed to things; to affix a stigma to a person; to affix ridicule or blame to any one.

African: A f r i c a n "n. A native of Africa; also one ethnologically belonging to an African race.

Africander: A f r i c a n d e r "n. One born in Africa  the offspring of a white father and a colored mother. Also and now commonly in Southern Africa a native born of European settlers.

Aft: A f t "adv. & a. Near or towards the stern of a vessel; astern; abaft.

After: A f t e r "a. Next; later in time; subsequent; succeeding; as  an after period of life.

After: A f t e r "a. Hinder; nearer the rear.

After: A f t e r "a. To ward the stern of the ship; -- applied to any object in the rear part of a vessel; as the after cabin  after hatchway.

After: A f t e r "prep. Behind in place; as  men in line one after another.

After: A f t e r "prep. Below in rank; next to in order.

After: A f t e r "prep. Later in time; subsequent; as  after supper after three days. It often precedes a clause. Formerly that was interposed between it and the clause.

After: A f t e r "prep. Subsequent to and in consequence of; as  after what you have said I shall be careful.

After: A f t e r "prep. Subsequent to and notwithstanding; as  after all our advice you took that course.

After: A f t e r "prep. Moving toward from behind; following  in search of; in pursuit of.

After: A f t e r "prep. Denoting the aim or object; concerning; in relation to; as  to look after workmen; to inquire after a friend; to thirst after righteousness.

After: A f t e r "prep. In imitation of; in conformity with; after the manner of; as  to make a thing after a model; a picture after Rubens; the boy takes after his father.

After: A f t e r "prep. According to; in accordance with; in conformity with the nature of; as  he acted after his kind.

After: A f t e r "prep. According to the direction and influence of; in proportion to; befitting.

After: A f t e r "adv. Subsequently in time or place; behind; afterward; as  he follows after.

After damp: A f t e r   d a m p " An irrespirable gas  remaining after an explosion of fire damp in mines; choke damp. See Carbonic acid.

After-dinner: A f t e r - d i n n e r "n. The time just after dinner.

After-dinner: A f t e r - d i n n e r "a. Following dinner; post-prandial; as  an after-dinner nap.

After-eatage: A f t e r - e a t a g e "n. Aftergrass.

After-glow: A f t e r - g l o w "n. A glow of refulgence in the western sky after sunset.

After-image: A f t e r - i m a g e "n. The impression of a vivid sensation retained by the retina of the eye after the cause has been removed; also extended to impressions left of tones  smells etc.

After-mentioned: A f t e r - m e n t i o n e d "a. Mentioned afterwards; as  persons after-mentioned (in a writing).

After-note: A f t e r - n o t e "n. One of the small notes occur on the unaccented parts of the measure  taking their time from the preceding note.

After-sails: A f t e r - s a i l s "n. The sails on the mizzenmast  or on the stays between the mainmast and mizzenmast.

After-wit: A f t e r - w i t "n. Wisdom or perception that comes after it can be of use.

After-witted: A f t e r - w i t t e d "a. Characterized by after-wit; slow-witted.

Afterbirth: A f t e r b i r t h "n. The placenta and membranes with which the fetus is connected  and which come away after delivery.

Aftercast: A f t e r c a s t "n. A throw of dice after the game in ended; hence  anything done too late.

Afterclap: A f t e r c l a p "n. An unexpected subsequent event; something disagreeable happening after an affair is supposed to be at an end.

Aftercrop: A f t e r c r o p "n. A second crop or harvest in the same year.

Aftereye: A f t e r e y e "v. t. To look after.

Aftergame: A f t e r g a m e "n. A second game; hence  a subsequent scheme or expedient.

Aftergrass: A f t e r g r a s s "n. The grass that grows after the first crop has been mown; aftermath.

Aftergrowth: A f t e r g r o w t h "n. A second growth or crop  or (metaphorically) development.

Afterguard: A f t e r g u a r d "n. The seaman or seamen stationed on the poop or after part of the ship  to attend the after-sails.

Afterings: A f t e r i n g s "n. pl. The last milk drawn in milking; strokings.

Aftermath: A f t e r m a t h "n. A second moving; the grass which grows after the first crop of hay in the same season; rowen.

Aftermost: A f t e r m o s t "a. superl. Hindmost; -- opposed to foremost.

Aftermost: A f t e r m o s t "a. superl. Nearest the stern; most aft.

Afternoon: A f t e r n o o n "n. The part of the day which follows noon  between noon and evening.

Afterpains: A f t e r p a i n s "n. pl. The pains which succeed childbirth  as in expelling the afterbirth.

Afterpiece: A f t e r p i e c e "n. A piece performed after a play  usually a farce or other small entertainment.

Afterpiece: A f t e r p i e c e "n. The heel of a rudder.

Aftershaft: A f t e r s h a f t "n. The hypoptilum.

Aftertaste: A f t e r t a s t e "n. A taste which remains in the mouth after eating or drinking.

Afterthought: A f t e r t h o u g h t "n. Reflection after an act; later or subsequent thought or expedient.

Afterward: A f t e r w a r d "adv. At a later or succeeding time.

Afterwards: A f t e r w a r d s "adv. Alt. of Afterward

Afterwise: A f t e r w i s e "a. Wise after the event; wise or knowing  when it is too late.

Aftmost: A f t m o s t "a. Nearest the stern.

Aftward: A f t w a r d "adv. Toward the stern.

Aga: A g a "n. Alt. of Agha

Again: A g a i n "adv. In return  back; as bring us word again.

Again: A g a i n "adv. Another time; once more; anew.

Again: A g a i n "adv. Once repeated; -- of quantity; as  as large again half as much again.

Again: A g a i n "adv. In any other place.

Again: A g a i n "adv. On the other hand.

Again: A g a i n "adv. Moreover; besides; further.

Again: A g a i n "prep. Alt. of Agains

Againbuy: A g a i n b u y "v. t. To redeem.

Agains: A g a i n s "prep. Against; also  towards (in order to meet).

Againsay: A g a i n s a y "v. t. To gainsay.

Against: A g a i n s t "prep. Abreast; opposite to; facing; towards; as  against the mouth of a river; -- in this sense often preceded by over.

Against: A g a i n s t "prep. From an opposite direction so as to strike or come in contact with; in contact with; upon; as  hail beats against the roof.

Against: A g a i n s t "prep. In opposition to  whether the opposition is of sentiment or of action; on the other side; counter to; in contrariety to; hence adverse to; as against reason; against law; to run a race against time.

Against: A g a i n s t "prep. By of before the time that; in preparation for; so as to be ready for the time when.

Againstand: A g a i n s t a n d "v. t. To withstand.

Againward: A g a i n w a r d "adv. Back again.

Agal-agal: A g a l - a g a l "n. Same as Agar-agar.

Agalactia: A g a l a c t i a "n. Alt. of Agalaxy

Agalactous: A g a l a c t o u s "a. Lacking milk to suckle with.

Agalaxy: A g a l a x y "n. Failure of the due secretion of milk after childbirth.

Agalloch: A g a l l o c h "n. Alt. of Agallochum

Agallochum: A g a l l o c h u m "n. A soft  resinous wood (Aquilaria Agallocha) of highly aromatic smell burnt by the orientals as a perfume. It is called also agalwood and aloes wood. The name is also given to some other species.

Agalmatolite: A g a l m a t o l i t e "n. A soft  compact stone of a grayish greenish or yellowish color carved into images by the Chinese and hence called figure stone and pagodite. It is probably a variety of pinite.

Agama: A g a m a "n. A genus of lizards  one of the few which feed upon vegetable substances; also one of these lizards.

Agami: A g a m i "n. A South American bird (Psophia crepitans)  allied to the cranes and easily domesticated; -- called also the gold-breasted trumpeter. Its body is about the size of the pheasant. See Trumpeter.

Agamic: A g a m i c "a. Produced without sexual union; as  agamic or unfertilized eggs.

Agamic: A g a m i c "a. Not having visible organs of reproduction  as flowerless plants; agamous.

Agamically: A g a m i c a l l y "adv. In an agamic manner.

Agamis: A g a m i s "pl. "of Agami

Agamist: A g a m i s t "n. An unmarried person; also  one opposed to marriage.

Agamogenesis: A g a m o g e n e s i s "n. Reproduction without the union of parents of distinct sexes: asexual reproduction.

Agamogenetic: A g a m o g e n e t i c "n. Reproducing or produced without sexual union.

Agamous: A g a m o u s "a. Having no visible sexual organs; asexual.

Agamous: A g a m o u s "a. cryptogamous.

Aganglionic: A g a n g l i o n i c "a. Without ganglia.

Agapae: A g a p a e "pl. "of Agape

Agape: A g a p e "adv. & a. Gaping  as with wonder expectation or eager attention.

Agape: A g a p e "n. The love feast of the primitive Christians  being a meal partaken of in connection with the communion.

Agar-agar: A g a r - a g a r "n. A fucus or seaweed much used in the East for soups and jellies; Ceylon moss (Gracilaria lichenoides).

Agaric: A g a r i c "n. A fungus of the genus Agaricus  of many species of which the common mushroom is an example.

Agaric: A g a r i c "n. An old name for several species of Polyporus  corky fungi growing on decaying wood.

Agasp: A g a s p "adv. & a. In a state of gasping.

Agast: A g a s t "v. t. Alt. of Aghast

Agast: A g a s t "p. p. & a. See Aghast.

Agastric: A g a s t r i c "a. Having to stomach  or distinct digestive canal as the tapeworm.

Agate: A g a t e "adv. On the way; agoing; as  to be agate; to set the bells agate.

Agate: A g a t e "n. A semipellucid  uncrystallized variety of quartz presenting various tints in the same specimen. Its colors are delicately arranged in stripes or bands or blended in clouds.

Agate: A g a t e "n. A kind of type  larger than pearl and smaller than nonpareil; in England called ruby.

Agate: A g a t e "n. A diminutive person; so called in allusion to the small figures cut in agate for rings and seals.

Agate: A g a t e "n. A tool used by gold-wire drawers  bookbinders etc.; -- so called from the agate fixed in it for burnishing.

Agatiferous: A g a t i f e r o u s "a. Containing or producing agates.

Agatine: A g a t i n e "a. Pertaining to  or like agate.

Agatize: A g a t i z e "v. t. To convert into agate; to make resemble agate.

Agaty: A g a t y "a. Of the nature of agate  or containing agate.

Agave: A g a v e "n. A genus of plants (order Amaryllidaceae) of which the chief species is the maguey or century plant (A. Americana)  wrongly called Aloe. It is from ten to seventy years according to climate in attaining maturity when it produces a gigantic flower stem sometimes forty feet in height and perishes. The fermented juice is the pulque of the Mexicans; distilled it yields mescal. A strong thread and a tough paper are made from the leaves and the wood has many uses.

Agazed: A g a z e d "p. p. Gazing with astonishment; amazed.

Age: A g e "n. The whole duration of a being  whether animal vegetable or other kind; lifetime.

Age: A g e "n. That part of the duration of a being or a thing which is between its beginning and any given time; as  what is the present age of a man or of the earth?

Age: A g e "n. The latter part of life; an advanced period of life; seniority; state of being old.

Age: A g e "n. One of the stages of life; as  the age of infancy of youth etc.

Age: A g e "n. Mature age; especially  the time of life at which one attains full personal rights and capacities; as to come of age; he (or she) is of age.

Age: A g e "n. The time of life at which some particular power or capacity is understood to become vested; as  the age of consent; the age of discretion.

Age: A g e "n. A particular period of time in history  as distinguished from others; as the golden age the age of Pericles.

Age: A g e "n. A great period in the history of the Earth.

Age: A g e "n. A century; the period of one hundred years.

Age: A g e "n. The people who live at a particular period; hence  a generation.

Age: A g e "n. A long time.

Age: A g e "v. i. To grow aged; to become old; to show marks of age; as  he grew fat as he aged.

Age: A g e "v. t. To cause to grow old; to impart the characteristics of age to; as  grief ages us.

Aged: A g e d "imp. & p. p. of Age

Aged: A g e d "a. Old; having lived long; having lived almost to or beyond the usual time allotted to that species of being; as  an aged man; an aged oak.

Aged: A g e d "a. Belonging to old age.

Aged: A g e d "a. Having a certain age; at the age of; having lived; as  a man aged forty years.

Agedly: A g e d l y "adv. In the manner of an aged person.

Agedness: A g e d n e s s "n. The quality of being aged; oldness.

Ageless: A g e l e s s "a. Without old age limits of duration; as  fountains of ageless youth.

Agen: A g e n "adv. & prep. See Again.

Agencies: A g e n c i e s "pl. "of Agency

Agency: A g e n c y "n. The faculty of acting or of exerting power; the state of being in action; action; instrumentality.

Agency: A g e n c y "n. The office of an agent  or factor; the relation between a principal and his agent; business of one intrusted with the concerns of another.

Agency: A g e n c y "n. The place of business of am agent.

Agend: A g e n d "n. See Agendum.

Agenda: A g e n d a "pl. "of Agendum

Agendum: A g e n d u m "n. Something to be done; in the pl.  a memorandum book.

Agendum: A g e n d u m "n. A church service; a ritual or liturgy. [In this sense  usually Agenda.]

Agenesic: A g e n e s i c "a. Characterized by sterility; infecund.

Agenesis: A g e n e s i s "n. Any imperfect development of the body  or any anomaly of organization.

Agennesis: A g e n n e s i s "n. Impotence; sterility.

Agent: A g e n t "a. Acting; -- opposed to patient  or sustaining action.

Agent: A g e n t "n. One who exerts power  or has the power to act; an actor.

Agent: A g e n t "n. One who acts for  or in the place of another by authority from him; one intrusted with the business of another; a substitute; a deputy; a factor.

Agent: A g e n t "n. An active power or cause; that which has the power to produce an effect; as  a physical chemical or medicinal agent; as heat is a powerful agent.

Agential: A g e n t i a l "a. Of or pertaining to an agent or an agency.

Agentship: A g e n t s h i p "n. Agency.

Ageratum: A g e r a t u m "n. A genus of plants  one species of which (A. Mexicanum) has lavender-blue flowers in dense clusters.

Aggeneration: A g g e n e r a t i o n "n. The act of producing in addition.

Agger: A g g e r "n. An earthwork; a mound; a raised work.

Aggerate: A g g e r a t e "v. t. To heap up.

Aggeration: A g g e r a t i o n "n. A heaping up; accumulation; as  aggerations of sand.

Aggerose: A g g e r o s e "a. In heaps; full of heaps.

Aggest: A g g e s t "v. t. To heap up.

Agglomerate: A g g l o m e r a t e "v. t. To wind or collect into a ball; hence  to gather into a mass or anything like a mass.

Agglomerate: A g g l o m e r a t e "v. i. To collect in a mass.

Agglomerate: A g g l o m e r a t e "a. Alt. of Agglomerated

Agglomerate: A g g l o m e r a t e "n. A collection or mass.

Agglomerate: A g g l o m e r a t e "n. A mass of angular volcanic fragments united by heat; -- distinguished from conglomerate.

Agglomerated: A g g l o m e r a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Agglomerate

Agglomerated: A g g l o m e r a t e d "a. Collected into a ball  heap or mass.

Agglomerated: A g g l o m e r a t e d "a. Collected into a rounded head of flowers.

Agglomerating: A g g l o m e r a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Agglomerate

Agglomeration: A g g l o m e r a t i o n "n. The act or process of collecting in a mass; a heaping together.

Agglomeration: A g g l o m e r a t i o n "n. State of being collected in a mass; a mass; cluster.

Agglomerative: A g g l o m e r a t i v e "a. Having a tendency to gather together  or to make collections.

Agglutinant: A g g l u t i n a n t "a. Uniting  as glue; causing or tending to cause adhesion.

Agglutinant: A g g l u t i n a n t "n. Any viscous substance which causes bodies or parts to adhere.

Agglutinate: A g g l u t i n a t e "v. t. To unite  or cause to adhere as with glue or other viscous substance; to unite by causing an adhesion of substances.

Agglutinate: A g g l u t i n a t e "a. United with glue or as with glue; cemented together.

Agglutinate: A g g l u t i n a t e "a. Consisting of root words combined but not materially altered as to form or meaning; as  agglutinate forms languages etc. See Agglutination 2.

Agglutinated: A g g l u t i n a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Agglutinate

Agglutinating: A g g l u t i n a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Agglutinate

Agglutination: A g g l u t i n a t i o n "n. The act of uniting by glue or other tenacious substance; the state of being thus united; adhesion of parts.

Agglutination: A g g l u t i n a t i o n "n. Combination in which root words are united with little or no change of form or loss of meaning. See Agglutinative  2.

Agglutinative: A g g l u t i n a t i v e "a. Pertaining to agglutination; tending to unite  or having power to cause adhesion; adhesive.

Agglutinative: A g g l u t i n a t i v e "a. Formed or characterized by agglutination  as a language or a compound.

Aggrace: A g g r a c e "v. t. To favor; to grace.

Aggrace: A g g r a c e "n. Grace; favor.

Aggrandizable: A g g r a n d i z a b l e "a. Capable of being aggrandized.

Aggrandization: A g g r a n d i z a t i o n "n. Aggrandizement.

Aggrandize: A g g r a n d i z e "v. t. To make great or greater in power  rank honor or wealth; -- applied to persons countries etc.

Aggrandize: A g g r a n d i z e "v. t. To make appear great or greater; to exalt.

Aggrandize: A g g r a n d i z e "v. i. To increase or become great.

Aggrandizer: A g g r a n d i z e r "n. One who aggrandizes  or makes great.

Aggrate: A g g r a t e "a. To please.

Aggravate: A g g r a v a t e "v. t. To make heavy or heavier; to add to; to increase.

Aggravate: A g g r a v a t e "v. t. To make worse  or more severe; to render less tolerable or less excusable; to make more offensive; to enhance; to intensify.

Aggravate: A g g r a v a t e "v. t. To give coloring to in description; to exaggerate; as  to aggravate circumstances.

Aggravate: A g g r a v a t e "v. t. To exasperate; to provoke; to irritate.

Aggravated: A g g r a v a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Aggravate

Aggravating: A g g r a v a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Aggravate

Aggravating: A g g r a v a t i n g "a. Making worse or more heinous; as  aggravating circumstances.

Aggravating: A g g r a v a t i n g "a. Exasperating; provoking; irritating.

Aggravatingly: A g g r a v a t i n g l y "adv. In an aggravating manner.

Aggravation: A g g r a v a t i o n "n. The act of aggravating  or making worse; -- used of evils natural or moral; the act of increasing in severity or heinousness; something additional to a crime or wrong and enhancing its guilt or injurious consequences.

Aggravation: A g g r a v a t i o n "n. Exaggerated representation.

Aggravation: A g g r a v a t i o n "n. An extrinsic circumstance or accident which increases the guilt of a crime or the misery of a calamity.

Aggravation: A g g r a v a t i o n "n. Provocation; irritation.

Aggravative: A g g r a v a t i v e "a. Tending to aggravate.

Aggravative: A g g r a v a t i v e "n. That which aggravates.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "v. t. To bring together; to collect into a mass or sum. The aggregated soil.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "v. t. To add or unite  as a person to an association.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "v. t. To amount in the aggregate to; as  ten loads aggregating five hundred bushels.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "a. Formed by a collection of particulars into a whole mass or sum; collective.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "a. Formed into clusters or groups of lobules; as  aggregate glands.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "a. Composed of several florets within a common involucre  as in the daisy; or of several carpels formed from one flower as in the raspberry.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "a. Having the several component parts adherent to each other only to such a degree as to be separable by mechanical means.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "a. United into a common organized mass; -- said of certain compound animals.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "n. A mass  assemblage or sum of particulars; as a house is an aggregate of stone brick timber etc.

Aggregate: A g g r e g a t e "n. A mass formed by the union of homogeneous particles; -- in distinction from a compound  formed by the union of heterogeneous particles.

Aggregated: A g g r e g a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Aggregate

Aggregately: A g g r e g a t e l y "adv. Collectively; in mass.

Aggregating: A g g r e g a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Aggregate

Aggregation: A g g r e g a t i o n "n. The act of aggregating  or the state of being aggregated; collection into a mass or sum; a collection of particulars; an aggregate.

Aggregative: A g g r e g a t i v e "a. Taken together; collective.

Aggregative: A g g r e g a t i v e "a. Gregarious; social.

Aggregator: A g g r e g a t o r "n. One who aggregates.

Aggrege: A g g r e g e "v. t. To make heavy; to aggravate.

Aggress: A g g r e s s "v. i. To commit the first act of hostility or offense; to begin a quarrel or controversy; to make an attack; -- with on.

Aggress: A g g r e s s "v. t. To set upon; to attack.

Aggress: A g g r e s s "n. Aggression.

Aggressed: A g g r e s s e d "imp. & p. p. of Aggress

Aggressing: A g g r e s s i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Aggress

Aggression: A g g r e s s i o n "n. The first attack  or act of hostility; the first act of injury or first act leading to a war or a controversy; unprovoked attack; assault; as a war of aggression. Aggressions of power.

Aggressive: A g g r e s s i v e "a. Tending or disposed to aggress; characterized by aggression; making assaults; unjustly attacking; as  an aggressive policy war person nation.

Aggressor: A g g r e s s o r "n. The person who first attacks or makes an aggression; he who begins hostility or a quarrel; an assailant.

Aggri: A g g r i "a. Applied to a kind of variegated glass beads of ancient manufacture; as  aggry beads are found in Ashantee and Fantee in Africa.

Aggrievance: A g g r i e v a n c e "n. Oppression; hardship; injury; grievance.

Aggrieve: A g g r i e v e "v. t. To give pain or sorrow to; to afflict; hence  to oppress or injure in one's rights; to bear heavily upon; -- now commonly used in the passive TO be aggrieved.

Aggrieve: A g g r i e v e "v. i. To grieve; to lament.

Aggrieved: A g g r i e v e d "imp. & p. p. of Aggrieve

Aggrieving: A g g r i e v i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Aggrieve

Aggroup: A g g r o u p "v. t. To bring together in a group; to group.

Aggroupment: A g g r o u p m e n t "n. Arrangement in a group or in groups; grouping.

Aggry: A g g r y "a. Alt. of Aggri

Agha: A g h a "n. In Turkey  a commander or chief officer. It is used also as a title of respect.

Aghast: A g h a s t "v. t. To affright; to terrify.

Aghast: A g h a s t "v. t. See Agast  v. t.

Aghast: A g h a s t "a & p. p. Terrified; struck with amazement; showing signs of terror or horror.

Agible: A g i b l e "a. Possible to be done; practicable.

Agile: A g i l e "a. Having the faculty of quick motion in the limbs; apt or ready to move; nimble; active; as  an agile boy; an agile tongue.

Agilely: A g i l e l y "adv. In an agile manner; nimbly.

Agileness: A g i l e n e s s "n. Agility; nimbleness.

Agility: A g i l i t y "n. The quality of being agile; the power of moving the limbs quickly and easily; nimbleness; activity; quickness of motion; as  strength and agility of body.

Agility: A g i l i t y "n. Activity; powerful agency.

Aging: A g i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Age

Agio: A g i o "n. The premium or percentage on a better sort of money when it is given in exchange for an inferior sort. The premium or discount on foreign bills of exchange is sometimes called agio.

Agios: A g i o s "pl. "of Agio

Agiotage: A g i o t a g e "n. Exchange business; also  stockjobbing; the maneuvers of speculators to raise or lower the price of stocks or public funds.

Agist: A g i s t "v. t. To take to graze or pasture  at a certain sum; -- used originally of the feeding of cattle in the king's forests and collecting the money for the same.

Agistator: A g i s t a t o r "n. See Agister.

Agister: A g i s t e r "n. Alt. of Agistor

Agistment: A g i s t m e n t "n. Formerly  the taking and feeding of other men's cattle in the king's forests.

Agistment: A g i s t m e n t "n. The taking in by any one of other men's cattle to graze at a certain rate.

Agistment: A g i s t m e n t "n. The price paid for such feeding.

Agistment: A g i s t m e n t "n. A charge or rate against lands; as  an agistment of sea banks i. e. charge for banks or dikes.

Agistor: A g i s t o r "n. Formerly  an officer of the king's forest who had the care of cattle agisted and collected the money for the same; -- hence called gisttaker which in England is corrupted into guest-taker.

Agistor: A g i s t o r "n. Now  one who agists or takes in cattle to pasture at a certain rate; a pasturer.

Agitable: A g i t a b l e "a. Capable of being agitated  or easily moved.

Agitate: A g i t a t e "v. t. To move with a violent  irregular action; as the wind agitates the sea; to agitate water in a vessel.

Agitate: A g i t a t e "v. t. To move or actuate.

Agitate: A g i t a t e "v. t. To stir up; to disturb or excite; to perturb; as  he was greatly agitated.

Agitate: A g i t a t e "v. t. To discuss with great earnestness; to debate; as  a controversy hotly agitated.

Agitate: A g i t a t e "v. t. To revolve in the mind  or view in all its aspects; to contrive busily; to devise; to plot; as politicians agitate desperate designs.

Agitated: A g i t a t e d "imp. & p. p. of Agitate

Agitatedly: A g i t a t e d l y "adv. In an agitated manner.

Agitating: A g i t a t i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Agitate

Agitation: A g i t a t i o n "n. The act of agitating  or the state of being agitated; the state of being moved with violence or with irregular action; commotion; as the sea after a storm is in agitation.

Agitation: A g i t a t i o n "n. A stirring up or arousing; disturbance of tranquillity; disturbance of mind which shows itself by physical excitement; perturbation; as  to cause any one agitation.

Agitation: A g i t a t i o n "n. Excitement of public feeling by discussion  appeals etc.; as the antislavery agitation; labor agitation.

Agitation: A g i t a t i o n "n. Examination or consideration of a subject in controversy  or of a plan proposed for adoption; earnest discussion; debate.

Agitative: A g i t a t i v e "a. Tending to agitate.

Agitato: A g i t a t o "a. Sung or played in a restless  hurried and spasmodic manner.

Agitator: A g i t a t o r "n. One who agitates; one who stirs up or excites others; as  political reformers and agitators.

Agitator: A g i t a t o r "n. One of a body of men appointed by the army  in Cromwell's time to look after their interests; -- called also adjutators.

Agitator: A g i t a t o r "n. An implement for shaking or mixing.

Agleam: A g l e a m "adv. & a. Gleaming; as  faces agleam.

Aglet: A g l e t "n. Alt. of Aiglet

Agley: A g l e y "adv. Aside; askew.

Aglimmer: A g l i m m e r "adv. & a. In a glimmering state.

Aglitter: A g l i t t e r "adv. & a. Glittering; in a glitter.

Aglossal: A g l o s s a l "a. Without tongue; tongueless.

Aglow: A g l o w "adv. & a. In a glow; glowing; as  cheeks aglow; the landscape all aglow.

Aglutition: A g l u t i t i o n "n. Inability to swallow.

Agminal: A g m i n a l "a. Pertaining to an army marching  or to a train.

Agminate: A g m i n a t e "a. Alt. of Agminated

Agminated: A g m i n a t e d "a. Grouped together; as  the agminated glands of Peyer in the small intestine.

Agnail: A g n a i l "n. A corn on the toe or foot.

Agnail: A g n a i l "n. An inflammation or sore under or around the nail; also  a hangnail.

Agnate: A g n a t e "a. Related or akin by the father's side; also  sprung from the same male ancestor.

Agnate: A g n a t e "a. Allied; akin.

Agnate: A g n a t e "n. A relative whose relationship can be traced exclusively through males.

Agnatic: A g n a t i c "a. Pertaining to descent by the male line of ancestors.

Agnation: A g n a t i o n "n. Consanguinity by a line of males only  as distinguished from cognation.

Agni: A g n i "pl. "of Agnus

Agnition: A g n i t i o n "n. Acknowledgment.

Agnize: A g n i z e "v. t. To recognize; to acknowledge.

Agnoiology: A g n o i o l o g y "n. The doctrine concerning those things of which we are necessarily ignorant.

Agnomen: A g n o m e n "n. An additional or fourth name given by the Romans  on account of some remarkable exploit or event; as Publius Caius Scipio Africanus.

Agnomen: A g n o m e n "n. An additional name  or an epithet appended to a name; as Aristides the Just.

Agnominate: A g n o m i n a t e "v. t. To name.

Agnomination: A g n o m i n a t i o n "n. A surname.

Agnomination: A g n o m i n a t i o n "n. Paronomasia; also  alliteration; annomination.

Agnostic: A g n o s t i c "a. Professing ignorance; involving no dogmatic; pertaining to or involving agnosticism.

Agnostic: A g n o s t i c "n. One who professes ignorance  or denies that we have any knowledge save of phenomena; one who supports agnosticism neither affirming nor denying the existence of a personal Deity a future life etc.

Agnosticism: A g n o s t i c i s m "n. That doctrine which  professing ignorance neither asserts nor denies.

Agnosticism: A g n o s t i c i s m "n. The doctrine that the existence of a personal Deity  an unseen world etc. can be neither proved nor disproved because of the necessary limits of the human mind (as sometimes charged upon Hamilton and Mansel) or because of the insufficiency of the evidence furnished by physical and physical data to warrant a positive conclusion (as taught by the school of Herbert Spencer); -- opposed alike dogmatic skepticism and to dogmatic theism.

Agnus: A g n u s "n. Agnus Dei.

Agnus castus: A g n u s   c a s t u s " A species of Vitex (V. agnus castus); the chaste tree.

Agnus Dei: A g n u s   D e i " A figure of a lamb bearing a cross or flag.

Agnus Dei: A g n u s   D e i " A cake of wax stamped with such a figure. It is made from the remains of the paschal candles and blessed by the Pope.

Agnus Dei: A g n u s   D e i " A triple prayer in the sacrifice of the Mass  beginning with the words Agnus Dei.

Agnuses: A g n u s e s "pl. "of Agnus

Ago: A g o "a. & adv. Past; gone by; since; as  ten years ago; gone long ago.

Agog: A g o g "a. & adv. In eager desire; eager; astir.

Agoing: A g o i n g "adv. In motion; in the act of going; as  to set a mill agoing.

Agon: A g o n "n. A contest for a prize at the public games.

Agone: A g o n e "a. & adv. Ago.

Agone: A g o n e "n. Agonic line.

Agones: A g o n e s "pl. "of Agon

Agonic: A g o n i c "a. Not forming an angle.

Agonies: A g o n i e s "pl. "of Agony

Agonism: A g o n i s m "n. Contention for a prize; a contest.

Agonist: A g o n i s t "n. One who contends for the prize in public games.

Agonistic: A g o n i s t i c "a. Alt. of Agonistical

Agonistical: A g o n i s t i c a l "a. Pertaining to violent contests  bodily or mental; pertaining to athletic or polemic feats; athletic; combative; hence strained; unnatural.

Agonistically: A g o n i s t i c a l l y "adv. In an agonistic manner.

Agonistics: A g o n i s t i c s "n. The science of athletic combats  or contests in public games.

Agonize: A g o n i z e "v. i. To writhe with agony; to suffer violent anguish.

Agonize: A g o n i z e "v. i. To struggle; to wrestle; to strive desperately.

Agonize: A g o n i z e "v. t. To cause to suffer agony; to subject to extreme pain; to torture.

Agonized: A g o n i z e d "imp. & p. p. of Agonize

Agonizing: A g o n i z i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Agonize

Agonizingly: A g o n i z i n g l y "adv. With extreme anguish or desperate struggles.

Agonothete: A g o n o t h e t e "n. An officer who presided over the great public games in Greece.

Agonothetic: A g o n o t h e t i c "a. Pertaining to the office of an agonothete.

Agony: A g o n y "n. Violent contest or striving.

Agony: A g o n y "n. Pain so extreme as to cause writhing or contortions of the body  similar to those made in the athletic contests in Greece; and hence extreme pain of mind or body; anguish; paroxysm of grief; specifically the sufferings of Christ in the garden of Gethsemane.

Agony: A g o n y "n. Paroxysm of joy; keen emotion.

Agony: A g o n y "n. The last struggle of life; death struggle.

Agood: A g o o d "adv. In earnest; heartily.

Agora: A g o r a "n. An assembly; hence  the place of assembly especially the market place in an ancient Greek city.

Agouara: A g o u a r a "n. The crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus)  found in the tropical parts of America.

Agouta: A g o u t a "n. A small insectivorous mammal (Solenodon paradoxus)  allied to the moles found only in Hayti.

Agouti: A g o u t i "n. Alt. of Agouty

Agouty: A g o u t y "n. A rodent of the genus Dasyprocta  about the size of a rabbit peculiar to South America and the West Indies. The most common species is the Dasyprocta agouti.

Agrace: A g r a c e "n. & v. See Aggrace.

Agraffe: A g r a f f e "n. A hook or clasp.

Agraffe: A g r a f f e "n. A hook  eyelet or other device by which a piano wire is so held as to limit the vibration.

Agrammatist: A g r a m m a t i s t "n. A illiterate person.

Agraphia: A g r a p h i a "n. The absence or loss of the power of expressing ideas by written signs. It is one form of aphasia.

Agraphic: A g r a p h i c "a. Characterized by agraphia.

Agrappes: A g r a p p e s "n. pl. Hooks and eyes for armor  etc.

Agrarian: A g r a r i a n "a. Pertaining to fields  or lands or their tenure; esp. relating to an equal or equitable division of lands; as the agrarian laws of Rome which distributed the conquered and other public lands among citizens.

Agrarian: A g r a r i a n "a. Wild; -- said of plants growing in the fields.

Agrarian: A g r a r i a n "n. One in favor of an equal division of landed property.

Agrarian: A g r a r i a n "n. An agrarian law.

Agrarianism: A g r a r i a n i s m "n. An equal or equitable division of landed property; the principles or acts of those who favor a redistribution of land.

Agrarianize: A g r a r i a n i z e "v. t. To distribute according to  or to imbue with the principles of agrarianism.

Agre: A g r e "adv. Alt. of Agree

Agree: A g r e e "adv. In good part; kindly.

Agree: A g r e e "v. i. To harmonize in opinion  statement or action; to be in unison or concord; to be or become united or consistent; to concur; as all parties agree in the expediency of the law.

Agree: A g r e e "v. i. To yield assent; to accede; -- followed by to; as  to agree to an offer or to opinion.

Agree: A g r e e "v. i. To make a stipulation by way of settling differences or determining a price; to exchange promises; to come to terms or to a common resolve; to promise.

Agree: A g r e e "v. i. To be conformable; to resemble; to coincide; to correspond; as  the picture does not agree with the original; the two scales agree exactly.

Agree: A g r e e "v. i. To suit or be adapted in its effects; to do well; as  the same food does not agree with every constitution.

Agree: A g r e e "v. i. To correspond in gender  number case or person.

Agree: A g r e e "v. t. To make harmonious; to reconcile or make friends.

Agree: A g r e e "v. t. To admit  or come to one mind concerning; to settle; to arrange; as to agree the fact; to agree differences.

Agreeability: A g r e e a b i l i t y "n. Easiness of disposition.

Agreeability: A g r e e a b i l i t y "n. The quality of being  or making one's self agreeable; agreeableness.

Agreeable: A g r e e a b l e "a. Pleasing  either to the mind or senses; pleasant; grateful; as agreeable manners or remarks; an agreeable person; fruit agreeable to the taste.

Agreeable: A g r e e a b l e "a. Willing; ready to agree or consent.

Agreeable: A g r e e a b l e "a. Agreeing or suitable; conformable; correspondent; concordant; adapted; -- followed by to  rarely by with.

Agreeable: A g r e e a b l e "a. In pursuance  conformity or accordance; -- in this sense used adverbially for agreeably; as agreeable to the order of the day the House took up the report.

Agreeableness: A g r e e a b l e n e s s "n. The quality of being agreeable or pleasing; that quality which gives satisfaction or moderate pleasure to the mind or senses.

Agreeableness: A g r e e a b l e n e s s "n. The quality of being agreeable or suitable; suitableness or conformity; consistency.

Agreeableness: A g r e e a b l e n e s s "n. Resemblance; concordance; harmony; -- with to or between.

Agreeably: A g r e e a b l y "adv. In an agreeably manner; in a manner to give pleasure; pleasingly.

Agreeably: A g r e e a b l y "adv. In accordance; suitably; consistently; conformably; -- followed by to and rarely by with. See Agreeable  4.

Agreeably: A g r e e a b l y "adv. Alike; similarly.

Agreed: A g r e e d "imp. & p. p. of Agree

Agreeing: A g r e e i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Agree

Agreeingly: A g r e e i n g l y "adv. In an agreeing manner (to); correspondingly; agreeably.

Agreement: A g r e e m e n t "n. State of agreeing; harmony of opinion  statement action or character; concurrence; concord; conformity; as a good agreement subsists among the members of the council.

Agreement: A g r e e m e n t "n. Concord or correspondence of one word with another in gender  number case or person.

Agreement: A g r e e m e n t "n. A concurrence in an engagement that something shall be done or omitted; an exchange of promises; mutual understanding  arrangement or stipulation; a contract.

Agreement: A g r e e m e n t "n. The language  oral or written embodying reciprocal promises.

Agreer: A g r e e r "n. One who agrees.

Agrestic: A g r e s t i c "a. Pertaining to fields or the country  in opposition to the city; rural; rustic; unpolished; uncouth.

Agrestical: A g r e s t i c a l "a. Agrestic.

Agricolation: A g r i c o l a t i o n "n. Agriculture.

Agricolist: A g r i c o l i s t "n. A cultivator of the soil; an agriculturist.

Agricultor: A g r i c u l t o r "n. An agriculturist; a farmer.

Agricultural: A g r i c u l t u r a l "a. Of or pertaining to agriculture; connected with  or engaged in tillage; as the agricultural class; agricultural implements wages etc.

Agriculturalist: A g r i c u l t u r a l i s t "n. An agriculturist (which is the preferred form.)

Agriculture: A g r i c u l t u r e "n. The art or science of cultivating the ground  including the harvesting of crops and the rearing and management of live stock; tillage; husbandry; farming.

Agriculturism: A g r i c u l t u r i s m "n. Agriculture.

Agriculturist: A g r i c u l t u r i s t "n. One engaged or skilled in agriculture; a husbandman.

Agrief: A g r i e f "adv. In grief; amiss.

Agrimony: A g r i m o n y "n. A genus of plants of the Rose family.

Agrimony: A g r i m o n y "n. The name is also given to various other plants; as  hemp agrimony (Eupatorium cannabinum); water agrimony (Bidens).

Agrin: A g r i n "adv. & a. In the act of grinning.

Agriologist: A g r i o l o g i s t "n. One versed or engaged in agriology.

Agriology: A g r i o l o g y "n. Description or comparative study of the customs of savage or uncivilized tribes.

Agrise: A g r i s e "v. i. To shudder with terror; to tremble with fear.

Agrise: A g r i s e "v. t. To shudder at; to abhor; to dread; to loathe.

Agrise: A g r i s e "v. t. To terrify; to affright.

Agrom: A g r o m "n. A disease occurring in Bengal and other parts of the East Indies  in which the tongue chaps and cleaves.

Agronomic: A g r o n o m i c " Alt. of Agronomical

Agronomical: A g r o n o m i c a l " Pertaining to agronomy  of the management of farms.

Agronomics: A g r o n o m i c s "n. The science of the distribution and management of land.

Agronomist: A g r o n o m i s t "n. One versed in agronomy; a student of agronomy.

Agronomy: A g r o n o m y "n. The management of land; rural economy; agriculture.

Agrope: A g r o p e "adv. & a. In the act of groping.

Agrostis: A g r o s t i s "n. A genus of grasses  including species called in common language bent grass. Some of them as redtop (Agrostis vulgaris) are valuable pasture grasses.

Agrostographic: A g r o s t o g r a p h i c "a. Alt. of Agrostographical

Agrostographical: A g r o s t o g r a p h i c a l "a. Pertaining to agrostography.

Agrostography: A g r o s t o g r a p h y "n. A description of the grasses.

Agrostologic: A g r o s t o l o g i c "a. Alt. of Agrostological

Agrostological: A g r o s t o l o g i c a l "a. Pertaining to agrostology.

Agrostologist: A g r o s t o l o g i s t "n. One skilled in agrostology.

Agrostology: A g r o s t o l o g y "n. That part of botany which treats of the grasses.

Aground: A g r o u n d "adv. & a. On the ground; stranded; -- a nautical term applied to a ship when its bottom lodges on the ground.

Agroupment: A g r o u p m e n t "n. See Aggroupment.

Agrypnotic: A g r y p n o t i c "n. Anything which prevents sleep  or produces wakefulness as strong tea or coffee.

Aguardiente: A g u a r d i e n t e "n. A inferior brandy of Spain and Portugal.

Aguardiente: A g u a r d i e n t e "n. A strong alcoholic drink  especially pulque.

Ague: A g u e "n. An acute fever.

Ague: A g u e "n. An intermittent fever  attended by alternate cold and hot fits.

Ague: A g u e "n. The cold fit or rigor of the intermittent fever; as  fever and ague.

Ague: A g u e "n. A chill  or state of shaking as with cold.

Ague: A g u e "v. t. To strike with an ague  or with a cold fit.

Agued: A g u e d "imp. & p. p. of Ague

Aguilt: A g u i l t "v. t. To be guilty of; to offend; to sin against; to wrong.

Aguise: A g u i s e "n. Dress.

Aguise: A g u i s e "v. t. To dress; to attire; to adorn.

Aguish: A g u i s h "a. Having the qualities of an ague; somewhat cold or shivering; chilly; shaky.

Aguish: A g u i s h "a. Productive of  or affected by ague; as the aguish districts of England.

Agush: A g u s h "adv. & a. In a gushing state.

Agynous: A g y n o u s "a. Without female organs; male.

Ah: A h "interj. An exclamation  expressive of surprise pity complaint entreaty contempt threatening delight triumph etc. according to the manner of utterance.

Aha: A h a "interj. An exclamation expressing  by different intonations triumph mixed with derision or irony or simple surprise.

Aha: A h a "n. A sunk fence. See Ha-ha.

Ahead: A h e a d "adv. In or to the front; in advance; onward.

Ahead: A h e a d "adv. Headlong; without restraint.

Aheap: A h e a p "adv. In a heap; huddled together.

Aheight: A h e i g h t "adv. Aloft; on high.

Ahem: A h e m "interj. An exclamation to call one's attention; hem.

Ahey: A h e y "interj. Hey; ho.

Ahigh: A h i g h "adv. On high.

Ahold: A h o l d "adv. Near the wind; as  to lay a ship ahold.

Ahorseback: A h o r s e b a c k "adv. On horseback.

Ahoy: A h o y "interj. A term used in hailing; as  Ship ahoy.

Ahriman: A h r i m a n "n. The Evil Principle or Being of the ancient Persians; the Prince of Darkness as opposer to Ormuzd  the King of Light.

Ahu: A h u "n. The Asiatic gazelle.

Ahull: A h u l l "adv. With the sails furled  and the helm lashed alee; -- applied to ships in a storm. See Hull n.

Ahungered: A h u n g e r e d "a. Pinched with hunger; very hungry.

Ai: A i "n. The three-toed sloth (Bradypus tridactylus) of South America. See Sloth.

Aiblins: A i b l i n s "adv. Alt. of Ablins

Aich's metal: A i c h ' s   m e t a l " A kind of gun metal  containing copper zinc and iron but no tin.

Aid: A i d "v. t. To support  either by furnishing strength or means in cooperation to effect a purpose or to prevent or to remove evil; to help; to assist.

Aid: A i d "v. t. Help; succor; assistance; relief.

Aid: A i d "v. t. The person or thing that promotes or helps in something done; a helper; an assistant.

Aid: A i d "v. t. A subsidy granted to the king by Parliament; also  an exchequer loan.

Aid: A i d "v. t. A pecuniary tribute paid by a vassal to his lord on special occasions.

Aid: A i d "v. t. An aid-de-camp  so called by abbreviation; as a general's aid.

Aid-de-camp: A i d - d e - c a m p "n. An officer selected by a general to carry orders  also to assist or represent him in correspondence and in directing movements.

Aid-major: A i d - m a j o r "n. The adjutant of a regiment.

Aidance: A i d a n c e "n. Aid.

Aidant: A i d a n t "a. Helping; helpful; supplying aid.

Aided: A i d e d "imp. & p. p. of Aid

Aider: A i d e r "n. One who  or that which aids.

Aidful: A i d f u l "a. Helpful.

Aiding: A i d i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Aid

Aidless: A i d l e s s "a. Helpless; without aid.

Aids-de-camp: A i d s - d e - c a m p "pl. "of Aid-de-camp

Aiel: A i e l "n. See Ayle.

Aiglet: A i g l e t "n. A tag of a lace or of the points  braids or cords formerly used in dress. They were sometimes formed into small images. Hence aglet baby (Shak.) an aglet image.

Aiglet: A i g l e t "n. A round white staylace.

Aiglet: A i g l e t "n. Same as Aglet.

Aigre: A i g r e "a. Sour.

Aigremore: A i g r e m o r e "n. Charcoal prepared for making powder.

Aigret: A i g r e t "n. Alt. of Aigrette

Aigrette: A i g r e t t e "n. The small white European heron. See Egret.

Aigrette: A i g r e t t e "n. A plume or tuft for the head composed of feathers  or of gems etc.

Aigrette: A i g r e t t e "n. A tuft like that of the egret.

Aigrette: A i g r e t t e "n. A feathery crown of seed; egret; as  the aigrette or down of the dandelion or the thistle.

Aiguille: A i g u i l l e "n. A needle-shaped peak.

Aiguille: A i g u i l l e "n. An instrument for boring holes  used in blasting.

Aiguillette: A i g u i l l e t t e "n. A point or tag at the end of a fringe or lace; an aglet.

Aiguillette: A i g u i l l e t t e "n. One of the ornamental tags  cords or loops on some military and naval uniforms.

Aigulet: A i g u l e t "n. See Aglet.

Ail: A i l "v. t. To affect with pain or uneasiness  either physical or mental; to trouble; to be the matter with; -- used to express some uneasiness or affection whose cause is unknown; as what ails the man? I know not what ails him.

Ail: A i l "v. i. To be affected with pain or uneasiness of any sort; to be ill or indisposed or in trouble.

Ail: A i l "n. Indisposition or morbid affection.

Ailanthus: A i l a n t h u s "n. Same as Ailantus.

Ailantus: A i l a n t u s "n. A genus of beautiful trees  natives of the East Indies. The tree imperfectly di/cious and the staminate or male plant is very offensive when blossom.

Ailed: A i l e d "imp. & p. p. of Ail

Ailette: A i l e t t e "n. A small square shield  formerly worn on the shoulders of knights -- being the prototype of the modern epaulet.

Ailing: A i l i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Ail

Ailment: A i l m e n t "n. Indisposition; morbid affection of the body; -- not applied ordinarily to acute diseases.

Ailuroidea: A i l u r o i d e a "n. pl. A group of the Carnivora  which includes the cats civets and hyenas.

Aim: A i m "v. i. To point or direct a missile weapon  or a weapon which propels as missile towards an object or spot with the intent of hitting it; as to aim at a fox or at a target.

Aim: A i m "v. i. To direct the indention or purpose; to attempt the accomplishment of a purpose; to try to gain; to endeavor; -- followed by at  or by an infinitive; as to aim at distinction; to aim to do well.

Aim: A i m "v. i. To guess or conjecture.

Aim: A i m "v. t. To direct or point  as a weapon at a particular object; to direct as a missile an act or a proceeding at to or against an object; as to aim a musket or an arrow the fist or a blow (at something); to aim a satire or a reflection (at some person or vice).

Aim: A i m "v. i. The pointing of a weapon  as a gun a dart or an arrow in the line of direction with the object intended to be struck; the line of fire; the direction of anything as a spear a blow a discourse a remark towards a particular point or object with a view to strike or affect it.

Aim: A i m "v. i. The point intended to be hit  or object intended to be attained or affected.

Aim: A i m "v. i. Intention; purpose; design; scheme.

Aim: A i m "v. i. Conjecture; guess.

Aimed: A i m e d "imp. & p. p. of Aim

Aimer: A i m e r "n. One who aims  directs or points.

Aiming: A i m i n g "p. pr. & vb. n. of Aim

Aimless: A i m l e s s "a. Without aim or purpose; as  an aimless life.

Ain't: A i n ' t " A contraction for are not and am not; also used for is not. [Colloq. or illiterate speech]. See An't.

Aino: A i n o "n. One of a peculiar race inhabiting Yesso  the Kooril Islands etc. in the northern part of the empire of Japan by some supposed to have been the progenitors of the Japanese. The Ainos are stout and short with hairy bodies.

Air: A i r "n. The fluid which we breathe  and which surrounds the earth; the atmosphere. It is invisible inodorous insipid transparent compressible elastic and ponderable.

Air: A i r "n. Symbolically: Something unsubstantial  light or volatile.

Air: A i r "n. A particular state of the atmosphere  as respects heat cold moisture etc. or as affecting the sensations; as a smoky air a damp air the morning air etc.

Air: A i r "n. Any aeriform body; a gas; as  oxygen was formerly called vital air.

Air: A i r "n. Air in motion; a light breeze; a gentle wind.

Air: A i r "n. Odoriferous or contaminated air.

Air: A i r "n. That which surrounds and influences.

Air: A i r "n. Utterance abroad; publicity; vent.

Air: A i r "n. Intelligence; information.
